BURGERS

All burgers are served with fries or garden salad.
ADD FRIED EGG 2
SUB CAESAR, GREEK, PEAR SALAD OR SWEET POTATO FRIES +$3

All dishes are served with fries or garden salad.

CLASSIC COCKTAILS

wood chip smoked +2

HARVEY WALLBANGER 1.5oz Spirit 11
Vodka, galliano, orange juice

The Harvey Wallbanger cocktail emerged in the 1950s or early 1960s. It is most commonly attributed to Donato "Duke" Antone, a bartender in Los Angeles, who supposedly created the drink and named it after a local surfer named Harvey. The story goes that Harvey, after a few too many of the cocktails, would bump into walls on his way out of the bar, thus earning the drink its memorable name. The cocktail gained widespread popularity in the 1970s thanks to a successful marketing campaign by George Bednar, a marketing executive for McKesson Imports Company, the importer of Galliano. The campaign featured a cartoon character, Harvey Wallbanger, which helped cement the drink's place in popular culture.

AMARETTO SOUR 2.5oz Spirit 14
Amaretto, bourbon, lemon, simple syrup, egg white

PAPER PLANE 2oz Spirit 14
Bourbon, Aperol, amaro

CABLE CAR 2oz Spirit 13
Spiced rum, dry curaçao, simple syrup, lemon

MARTINI 3oz Spirit 14
Gin/vodka, dry vermouth, orange bitters

According to historians and locals, the cocktail was invented in the mid-1800s during the California Gold Rush era. A miner, wishing to celebrate his luck in his search for gold, is said to have asked for champagne at a local bar to mark the occasion. The barman, not having any, insisted on creating a cocktail with the ingredients available at the time: gin, vermouth, bitters, maraschino liqueur, and lemon.

An emblem of sophistication and elegance, the Martini's allure only grew, becoming a staple of American culture. Its popularity soared in the mid-20th century, immortalized by icons such as James Bond. However, it was the 1960s that cemented the Martini's place in pop culture, thanks to the hit television series Mad Men. The show's lead character, Don Draper, often seen sipping a Martini, epitomized the cocktail's association with power, style, and the sophisticated yet tumultuous world of advertising. Mad Men reignited interest in the Martini, celebrating its role as a timeless symbol of mid-century glamour.

NEGRONI/BOULEVARDIER 3oz Spirit 14
Gin/Rye, Campari, sweet vermouth

Originated in Florence, Italy, in 1919. Count Camillo Negroni, seeking a stronger version of his favorite cocktail, the Americano, requested bartender Fosco Scarselli at Caffè Casoni to replace soda water with gin. The result was a bold, balanced drink that quickly gained popularity. The Negroni's vibrant red hue and perfectly balanced bittersweet profile made it an instant classic. Over the decades, it has become a symbol of Italian aperitivo culture, celebrated for its simplicity and elegance. The cocktail's legacy endures, with countless variations and a dedicated global following, making it a timeless icon of refined taste and Italian sophistication.

DAIQUIRI 2oz Spirit 12

FRENCH 75 2oz Spirit 3oz Sparkling 14
Gin, lemon, sparkling wine

The French 75 cocktail, or in French simply a Soixante Quinze, has a history as vibrant and explosive as its flavors. Named after the French 75mm field gun, renowned for its power and precision during World War I, this cocktail was said to be first concocted by English soldiers fighting in France during the First World War. These soldiers took the only raw ingredients they had on hand, allegedly, and combined gin, fresh lemon juice, sugar, and Champagne, 1 serving the whole concoction in a 75-millimeter artillery shell.
